posts.post_content:
I agree with these cards being beyond jokes, its pathetic, I mean look at it, ITS NOT A JOKE!  
  
Chimney Imp makes you opponents cry, for 5, you get a 1/2 mostly unblockable beast, that if they manage to remove, will take a card with them?! WHAT are they going to do?  
  
A 20 turn clock that starts turn 6, maybe earlier with [Black Lotus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Lotus) or [Dark Ritual](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dark Ritual) OR they lose a card, like a discard, and then waste a kill spell, and set them back a draw?  
  
OP, I can't believe it saw print, lucky affinity was there to kinda level the game.  
5/5

posts.post_content:
You know what's an awesome combo with this card?  
  
Turn 1:Mountain, Rite of flame, Rite of flame, Rite of flame, Rite of flame, Desperate ritual (spliced desperate ritual), desperate ritual, manamorphose, ancestral recall, chimney imp, lotus petal, manamorphose, dragon storm!  
  
Search for: 4 Blades of Velis Vel, 4 Crib Swaps, and 4 Boggardan Hellkites!  
  
Turn 1 win! This card is insane!  
  
Who could dispute how great this card is!  
  
I've actually never even resolved this card: My opponent always concedes if they don't have a counterspell in hand.  
  
Also, another great combo? First turn, on their upkeep, start with [gemstone caverns](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=gemstone caverns) in play. Then remove a [simian spirit guide](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=simian spirit guide) from your hand, tap the caverns for blue, and cast flash. Put a chimney imp into play. Your opponent will be forced to put a card from their hand on top of their library!

posts.post_content:
Every once and a while a card comes around that defines the entire metagame of MTG. Skullclamp, Jitte, ect.   
  
Chimney Imp blows any card previously mentioned out of the water, it's so good it completely destroyed the current meatgame and created a new one, which it then proceeded to destroy.  
  
It is said that grinding a chimney imp into a fine powder and snorting it will make the user the ultimate magic player, but no man has been willing to sacrifice a card this wonderful for a skill gain.  
  
This card is a diamond, shining out from the middle of the rough. Life is Chimney Imp.

posts.post_content:
For you crybabies whining about the casting cost, you're completely forgetting that you get to untap those five lands on your VERY NEXT TURN with no drawback whatsoever.  
  
Also, it absolutely obliterates your opponent's pace if it dies - but good luck trying to kill it, because it's immune to [deathmark](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=deathmark).  
  
If that isnt enough, it has rampage: 0, so you can attack every turn without fear. Chimney Imp LIVES SIDEWAYS.

posts.post_content: I run a black/white deck that absolutely abuses the [Stuffy Doll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stuffy Doll), [Guilty Conscience](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Guilty Conscience), [Chimney Imp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chimney Imp) combo. When I show my opponent my hand of [Swamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swamp), [Swamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Swamp), [Plains](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plains), [Plains](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plains), [Plains](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plains), [One with Nothing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=One with Nothing), [Chimney Imp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chimney Imp), they always scoop. The threat of this menace coming on turn five (possibly turn 3 if I draw [Dark Ritual](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dark Ritual)) is too much for them. I don't blame my opponent, though. This card is just that good.

posts.post_content:
A while ago, a friend of mine was playing some sort of wacky ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol) deck against my ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) control deck. At some point in the game, he cast [Chimney Imp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chimney Imp). I wasn't very good at Magic back then, so I thought to myself, "Meh, I've seen better." He then enchanted it with [Splinter Twin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Splinter Twin) and [Pemmin's Aura](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pemmin's Aura). Like an amateur, I wasn't impressed; I still thought it was a mediocre card, enchanted with two mediocre auras. Then he dropped [Phyrexian Altar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Altar).  
  
Suddenly realizing what was happening, I looked at my hand. [Vendetta](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vendetta), [Terror](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terror), [Radiant's Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Radiant's Judgment)...all useless. In desperation, I equipped a [Skullclamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Skullclamp) to my [Solemn Simulacrum](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Solemn Simulacrum) and then [Annihilate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Annihilate)d it, hoping to draw an answer. Luckily, my third card was [Path to Exile](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Path to Exile), although I didn't draw anything else useful. So ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
A while ago, a friend of mine was playing some sort of wacky deck against my control deck. At some point in the game, he cast Chimney Imp. I wasn't very good at Magic back then, so I thought to myself, "Meh, I've seen better." He then enchanted it with Splinter Twin and Pemmin's Aura. Like an amateur, I wasn't impressed; I still thought it was a mediocre card, enchanted with two mediocre auras. Then he dropped Phyrexian Altar.

Suddenly realizing what was happening, I looked at my hand. Vendetta, Terror, Radiant's Judgment...all useless. In desperation, I equipped a Skullclamp to my Solemn Simulacrum and then Annihilated it, hoping to draw an answer. Luckily, my third card was Path to Exile, although I didn't draw anything else useful. So ... (see all)

posts.post_content:
The real game-breaking part is that he has flying. Even [Chittering Rats](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chittering Rats) doesn't have that and all for just 2 extra mana. Too broken, I say.  
  
Also survives [spark spray](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=spark spray), can block fear and flying, can fight off turn-1 [Champion of the Parish](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Champion of the Parish) and [Birds of Paradise](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Birds of Paradise) and un-buffed [Tarmogoyf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tarmogoyf), fizzles [doomblade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=doomblade) and [terror](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=terror), can't be blocked by [darksteel colossus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=darksteel colossus), and forces your opponent to potentially waste a [wrath of god](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=wrath of god). Even then, he still trolls you after dying by slowing down your tempo so you can't top deck something to save yourself. Even [black lotus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=black lotus) dies to naturalize, [ancestrall recal](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=ancestrall recal) and [time walk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=time walk) can be countered with negate [Negate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Negate). Not Chimney Imp though.
posts.html:
The real game-breaking part is that he has flying. Even Chittering Rats doesn't have that and all for just 2 extra mana. Too broken, I say.

Also survives spark spray, can block fear and flying, can fight off turn-1 Champion of the Parish and Birds of Paradise and un-buffed Tarmogoyf, fizzles doomblade and terror, can't be blocked by darksteel colossus, and forces your opponent to potentially waste a wrath of god. Even then, he still trolls you after dying by slowing down your tempo so you can't top deck something to save yourself. Even black lotus dies to naturalize, ancestrall recal and time walk can be countered with negate Negate. Not Chimney Imp though.

posts.post_content:
It's a little known fact, but Chimney Imp was originally supposed to be Mythic Rare.  
  
However, on the day of the printing, it turned out that the printer at Wizards had run out of both golden and silver paint. (Rumors have it that this was due to sabotage by a secret society called the ***Imp**lumminati*, consisting of the wealthiest Magic players around the world.) Therefore, Wizards couldn't make it Mythic Rare, nor even Uncommon. Faced with this roadblock, the company had no choice but to make Chimney Imp common, despite knowing how powerful it is. **And that's why Mirrodin is broken.**  
  
Honestly, did you REALLY believe a card THIS powerful could ever have been intended to be a simple common? Come on, all around the world people *sing* the praises of Chimney Imp. You think this is just a figure of speech? They literally **sing them.**  
  
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wEVSahgCegk
posts.html:
It's a little known fact, but Chimney Imp was originally supposed to be Mythic Rare.

However, on the day of the printing, it turned out that the printer at Wizards had run out of both golden and silver paint. (Rumors have it that this was due to sabotage by a secret society called the Implumminati, consisting of the wealthiest Magic players around the world.) Therefore, Wizards couldn't make it Mythic Rare, nor even Uncommon. Faced with this roadblock, the company had no choice but to make Chimney Imp common, despite knowing how powerful it is. And that's why Mirrodin is broken.

Honestly, did you REALLY believe a card THIS powerful could ever have been intended to be a simple common? Come on, all around the world people sing the praises of Chimney Imp. You think this is just a figure of speech? They literally sing them.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wEVSahgCegk
